content.description: A little bit cruxy before the roof.  Don't cheat your self out of a great stem to surmount the roof.  It is only .10- after all.
content.location: Third from the left on the wall.  The trail meets the wall at base of this route.  Route goes through a small roof at the top.

content.description:
Great route of bouldery limestone pocket pulling. Fun moves through the steep sections and an engaging though less steep headwall keeps things interesting to the top.

This route is rated .12b in the old Cody guidebook, but it seems the consensus is .12a.
content.location: Furthest route left in the steep section of the Hideout Wall. Just left of Hideout.

content.description: This route tackles the cleft formed at the right side of the roof.  You'll find yourself upside down working good pockets gunning for the lip.  The crux is rounding the lip in an efficient manner, which may include hanging and clipping a draw.  The headwall above is no gimmie and rests are few.  The crack to the right isn't used as it is quite dirty and there is a perfect line of pockets and edges up the face.  This line is my favorite on the wall.
content.location: On the right side of the roof. Start on the back wall and angle up left into the cleft.  To the right of Butch 12c.

content.description: The first 4 bolts are the toughest. Really good route!
content.protection: 6 bolts, shares sport anchor with High and Dry.
content.location: Second route from the left and basically right where the trail meets the wall.

content.description: Pockets and edges lead to a tough move through the steepest section and continue to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts, shares sport anchor with In the Middle.
content.location: Left most route on the wall.  Step between the bush and the boulder and scramble to the ledge to begin.

content.description:
Getting through the roof is obviously the business although the upper headwall is fun too.

This route was established on lead to 'open' this wall either by Tood Cozzens or Richard Plummer in 1994.
content.location: Right of On the Run and left of Bite the Bullet.  Follows the crack through the roof.

content.description: Step on and move up to where you can dyno for the obvious pocket.  Some have statically reached it but its a stretch.  Why not just huck for it?
content.location: Right of Bite the Bullet and left of The Kid.  Climbs just left of the prow.

climbs.name: The Brothel
climbs.fa: Mike Snyder, equipped by Steve Moore

content.description: Grab the pocket on the lip at about 6 feet up.  Campus up to good pockets and swing your foot up on the rock, press your way up to a good hold.  The rest is cake, go through the roof and up the dihedral.   Good route.
content.location: Just right of Trail Town and left of On the Run.

climbs.name: Bite the Bullet
climbs.fa: Est by Rick Aune, FA unknown

content.description: Desperately crimpy holds going through the roof.  Stick clip?!
content.location: Right of The Hideout and left of Butch.

climbs.name: Betty Swalls
climbs.fa: Equipped by Mike Snyder, FA Leif Gasch

content.description: Steep at bottom to a slab to a small roof at the top
content.location: Starts 15 feet right of the steep roof section.
